isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - LIFT AXLE SYSTEMS - SELF-STEERING AXLE ASSEMBLIES

svcproc.title: DESCRIPTION
svcproc.para: The self-steering axles reduce tire wear; but are more complex than fixed axles. Self-steering axles are similar to front, non-driving, steering axles. Like a front axle, the steering arms and knuckles at the ends of the self-steer axle are connected by a tie rod so that both tires on the axle track together. A spring-loaded self-centering mechanism keeps the tires aimed straight ahead until the drag created by cornering causes the tires to deflect, or steer, in the direction that creates the least rolling resistance. As the direction of travel straightens out the self-centering mechanism returns the tires to their straight ahead position.
The self-steer axle currently used has a 13,200 pound load capacity. The self-steer axle may be used in any lift axle location and in any combination.

Self-centering self-steering axles can only track while moving forward. Backing up with the auxiliary suspension in the down position can result in damage to the steering components of the axle; therefore, the self-steering lift axles must be lifted when the truck is in reverse. Factory installed self-steering lift axles include a control system that automatically raises all lift axle assemblies when the truck is put into reverse.
Some features of the 13,200 pound capacity self-steering lift axle are:

item.para: a rubber bushed two pin axle connection
standard hubs and drums are cast 10 hole - 11.25in bc unimount
standard brakes system includes 15x4 Meritor Q-Plus brakes, Type 20 MGM chambers, 931 - 162 Federal Mogul brake linings, and a Meritor slack adjuster.
